description:
Welcome to the Dodgeball World Tour! This game is designed to create an experience akin to Vince Vaughn and Ben Stiller’s movie version of professional dodgeball, but presented as a touring road show, similar to professional wrestling. On the Dodgeball World Tour, an ever-evolving collection of teams travel from city to city, entertaining fans with a nightly program that features an escalating series of matches.

Put together your team, line up on the court, rush for the balls, roll dice to score hits on your opponents and the team with the last player standing wins. Advance on the tour, improve your TV ratings and become the Dodgeball World Tour champion.

Deal 52 cards (or 36 if three play. For 2 players, see below) ranking AKQJT9876(5432). Deal them all out in ones. If five play, discard the odd two.

The objective is to win tricks of higher rather than lower value. The player with the highest number of points, wins.

Dealer's left-hand neighbour leads to the first trick. You must follow suit if you can, but may otherwise play any card. The trick is taken by the highest card of the suit led and the winner of each trick leads to the next.

Each trick is worth a different value, with values ascending, then dropping in value, then ascending again over the course of 10-13 tricks (depending on player count).

Object
To win tricks, especially by playing two cards with the greatest possible difference between them. For this purpose cards have numerical values from Ace = 1 up to King=13. Thus if the cards you play are King-Ace the difference between them is 12 (=13-1), while if they are equal the difference is zero.

Each trick must contain exactly one card of each suit.

ãƒ¦ãƒ“ã‚¨ã‚¤ãƒ  (You Be Aim) is a 2 player flicking game from Japan. The publisher Protocraft focuses on games with miniatures of mechas (brutalist robots). Players have a crawling mecha each, and must move around the factory to achieve goals. The mecha has a hollow body and the player loads a cylinder into the mecha and then fires it across the board by flicking the back of the mecha.

The game board in You Be Aim is double-sided, so players can play two different games. In one game, Watari Usagi (ã‚ãŸã‚Šã†ã•ãŽ), they aim to fire cylinders at the rabbit robots of their opponent. In the other game, Jitsuriki Sugoroku (å®ŸåŠ›ã™ã”ã‚ã), the players must move around the factory and fire at targets on the walls without hitting the rabbit robots.

Customers who reserved early for the game at the Tokyo Game Market got a free metal miniature rabbit robot.
user summary

This game is based on Phat, a Scottish member of the All Fours family (whose members include Pitch, Pedro, and Don).

Twenty-one tricks are played each hand; the object is to peg points on a Cribbage board for capturing valuable cards. The game end is triggered when someone pegs 180 (or more) points. The hand is completed and the player with the higher score wins.

The game is quite simple to teach as it uses standard must-follow trick-taking. To increase balance, one player will pick a trump suit and the other player will pick the rank order (which cards are high or low). What elevates the game is its distribution of card points among the ranks; in particular, trying to avoid giving up the high Phat points for capturing the middle-ranking 9s makes for some interesting and sometimes quite tense decisions.

Players are given dice with symbols and minus or plus points. The dice are rolled simultaneously. Whoever rolls a red emoji may place it in the center of the game (if there are not already 3). A die with a green emoji must be passed on to the next player. A round is over when there are 3 red emojis in the center. Then each player counts his current plus or minus points and gets paid chips accordingly. Otherwise, the players continue to roll the dice. Whoever has collected the most plus points after 7 rounds wins the game.

æœ­æŸã¨æº¶é‰±ç‚‰ (Satsutaba to Youkouro) is a 2 player bluffing card game from Japan. The players take two roles; one is building a road and the other is building on the road side. The designer likens the game to Skull. The game title translates as "Bankrolls and Blast Furnaces". The player who most recently fell into a blast furnace gets to go first.

One player arranges five good tiles (bankrolls) and one bad tile (a blast furnace) in a face-down line. The other player turns them over from left to right until they want to stop.

The turning player gets a point for each good tile they turned over, a bonus two points if they stopped just before the bad tile, and no points at all if they turned over the bad tile.

The placing player gets a point for each good tile they placed before the bad tile (i.e. each one that the turning player had an opportunity to take), plus a bonus two points if the turning player turned over the bad tile.

Swap places and do it again, do all of that three times with double points in the last round, whoever has the most points wins.
user summary

Unconventional tabletop warfare!

Each player is dealt one HQ card, which has its own tactical advantage. Players are then dealt cards, on their turns they draw a card and play a card, attack or defense. Forge and break alliances, wars on all fronts, the table is your warzone!

Each HQ can within stand 20 points of damage before falling, the damage is inflicted by horseshoes, hand grenades, and nukes! There are cards to repair your damage, but remember, nuclear damage is not repairable! Once your HQ hits 20 points of damage, you are out of the game, last HQ standing wins.

—description from designer

Inspired by real life synchronized swimming, Sync or Swim focuses on teamwork, collaboration, and communication.

Each round,  teammates plan the perfect routine while taking direction from the team captain. The clock starts and players start trading, placing, and diving for cards to get their performance just right. As your team progresses through each round, the routines become more challenging and throw all sorts of twists your way!

At the end of each round, the free app judges your performance based on your timing and accuracy—You and your friends will discover creative tactics for better strategies and scores each time you play.

—description from the publisher

Syndicate Ultimatum is set in the cyberpunk world of the future. The world is under control of the World Syndicate, in whose hands all power is concentrated. But there are Corporation Cities that are not subject to him.

In one of those cities - Helios - one of two players take on role of Stella - daughter of deceased head of the city, and other player become Roy - successor of Stella's father. Remember: Helios can only have one ruler! Who will become it? Players only have 24 hours to determine this...

The struggle take place in five districts of the city. The goal of each player is to take control of more districts than his opponent. The game consists of two rounds, according to the results of which the winner is determined.

Players in their turns place tokens from their player boards in an attempt to earn as many Victory Points (VP) as possible. Each type of tokens(there are five of them in the game) has its own abilities and its own strength. A district is considered to be under control of player if total power of his tokens in it is greater than that of the opponent. Each controlled district in the round end is worth one VP to player.

But not everything is so simple. The game has 25 unique district cards that allow players to make changes on the struggle field. When player playing a card from his hand, he applies its ability and then places it on the Timer represent the hour counter.

As soon as the twelfth card is placed on Timer, the round ends. The game ends after second round ends. Player with most VP is winner, in case of a tie both players are loosers, and Syndicate is enslave Helios.

The game has an asymmetry module represented by four special Boss ability cards — the main tokens of players. Placing the Boss token on an district, the player applies its ability, which can frustrate all the opponent's plans.

The game can also be played in tournament mode. In this case, players do not receive points for each controlled area. Instead, player receives one victory point if he wins the round. The game lasts up to two wins of one of the players.

A classic in the red glitter dress that characterizes all games in this series. The title promises "Your first checkers game", the board is in checkerboard pattern with shamrocks and empty squares, the pieces are Mickey Mouse for one player and Donald Duck for the other. Movement rules are similar to those of checkers, but the goal is to be the first to get your pieces to the other side, with your opponent's pieces and the neutral frogs getting in the way.

—user summary

ãƒšãƒ³ã‚®ãƒ³ã‚»ãƒ³ã‚¹ (Penguin Sense) is a push your luck game from Japan. As Emperor Penguins, players swim out to see in search of food for their young. But they risk being attacked by predators such as seals or orcos.

Each player takes turns to take a food chip, worth 1-4, and then flip the Sea Card underneath the chip. Each card shows some aspect of life at sea, some are good fortune, some are bad luck.

Players can choose when to give up feeding and return to shore, but they cannot go out again. The game ends when either all the penguins have gone back, or when a second orca appears, which means any penguin still at sea loses all their food.

Of the penguins that got back home, the one with the most food value is the winner.

The game cards includes information, so the game is good for educating children (who can read Japanese).
user summary

From Dunder Mifflin's Scranton branch and What Do You Meme? comes the best use of cardstock paper yet – introducing What Do You Meme? The Office Edition! Now you can meme your favorite characters and moments from the iconic show – Prison Mike, the Party Planning Committee, and Pretzel Day included, of course. Do this by using one of your dealt caption cards to caption the photo card in play. A rotating judge picks the winning combo each round! The Office marathon plus game night, anyone?

Includes: 300 caption cards, 75 photo cards, 1 easel for displaying photo cards and instructions

Imagine a baseball game where you call all the shots, not just your team but your team, your league, your world! On-deck baseball is an immersive table-top baseball experience where you have the ability to create a fictional baseball world on your terms.

On-Deck Baseball is a simplified version of Strat-O-Matic that allows players to create a base of players that were not tied to reality, a fictional universe. Percentages are all based off of 10s therefore it made the most sense to use the D10 die (a 10 sided die) so a person can truly see a representation of the percentages as possible outcomes, incorporating the use of a rolling matrix, result are obtained by cross reference the rolls of 2 different die, in this case a red and blue die.

Honour and Arms is a fantasy adventure game played on a map of a small unnamed region. Each player controls a character; there are 16 characters supplied, differentiated by their values in six different traits, their special abilities, and their alignments.

On a turn a player rolls a die for their number of movement points and then moves from space to space on the map. In each new space a die is rolled to determine how many (if any) encounter cards need to be drawn. Encounters may be items which can be taken or may be beings which can be fought or bargained with, or in some cases taken on as minions. Fighting provide experience, either physical or psychic, and when a character has three experience of a type they must turn them in for increases in traits.

There are a number of fixed locations on the board with special rules in a separate adventure booklet, and in some cases special decks of encounter cards. There are also minor locations which have cards in the standard decks and are placed on the board once found.

There are rules for encumbrance, player vs. player combat, healing, etc. Players may band together as a group. Some activities are regulated by alignment, of which there are two kinds: good vs. evil and imperial vs. rebel. For example, good characters can't attack without provocation.

There are several ways to win the game, all dependent on alignment. For example, a good character can achieve a spiritual victory by entering the Nether Realm and defeating the Prince of Darkness, while a rebel character can achieve a political victory by finding the king in his keep and defeating him. Some ways require finding the five rings forming the Hand of Fate, but if a character wears all of them at once they may become bewitched by them, in which case they get special powers but then can only win by killing all the other characters. The rules suggest that for a shorter game a time limit is set and then if no one has achieved a victory condition, a scoring rubric is provided.

The game of Inter-Rail is about traveling around Europe, by train, experience as much as possible, buy souvenirs to take home, and in that way get most points to win the game.

You do this by rolling the die, move around the board, and land on spaces to draw city or chance cards. This goes on for a specified amount of time, usually 1-2 hours, and when you get home to Start (Oslo), you draw point cards to see how valuable your purchased items are.

The player with most points wins the game.

—user summary

ç§ç«‹ã‚´ãƒ­åˆãƒ¯ã‚»å¤§å­¦ (Shiritsu goro gÅ wase daigaku) (Pun University) is a party game from Japan. ç§ç«‹ã‚´ãƒ­åˆãƒ¯ã‚»å¤§å­¦ translates as Private Goro Goiwase University. Players are trying to pass the university entrance exam, which requires making witty puns.

Players take turns to be the examiner and select a topic from two cards. Once declared, the players write puns on their whiteboards, and get a few seconds more after one player stops.

The puns are read out, and the players award points to the best.

Then the examiner asks questions. Players have to pass the exam questions using the puns read out.

After a few rounds, the player with the most points is the winner.

This game is the second in a series of 'Nappy' games by the publisher.
user summary

Doppeldoppel is a trick-taking game for 3 to 4 players about carrying souls down to a lower world.  However, if two souls descend at the same time, they will disappear!

The game uses an irregular deck of cards, with 1-3 cards in each of ranks 1-6 in each of 3 suits.  Depending upon the player count, some cards are played face down, and others face up, but it is a "must-follow" game, and the highest ranked card of the lead suit will win.  However, in keeping with the theme, if two or more cards of the same rank are played, they are removed from consideration.

The winner of the trick collects any remaining cards into a score pile.  All cards start at -1 points, but each rank has a unique scoring or play affect.  For instance, if you have at least three cards of rank 1, each of your rank 1 cards is worth +2 points instead of -1; each rank 5 card is worth +7 points if you have no rank 6 cards.

The game lasts a number of rounds equal to the number of players; at the end, the person with the most points wins.

Nervos is a real-time puzzle game that combines elements of Ubongo with Ghost Blitz.

The game includes a stack of puzzle cards and 4 polyomino pieces.  Each puzzle card shows a shape that can be made using exactly 3 of the pieces.  A puzzle card is revealed and the players race, mentally, to determine which piece is not used.  Once they feel confident, they grab the piece, and then have a few seconds to "show their work" by completing the shape with the other pieces.

The games ends when a player successfully completes 4 cards; alternatively, players are eliminated if they incorrectly answer 3 cards.

"In a little village in Fairy Tale Land, there lived a friendly old doctor, who all his life wanted nothing more than to help people. Whenever a call came in, he grabbed his bag and rushed to the patient's bedside. Very often, however, he found that in his haste, he had brought the wrong cure. But did that stop him? No, he tried anyway, and, funny as it may seem, his patients would always get well."

Players each choose a color of playing piece, and place them on Doctor Quack's house in the center of the playing board, to start. Each player draws one Cure Card. Players spin to see who goes first.

In order to reach the different cases, players take turns spinning and moving their playing piece along a path of their choice. When they land on a case space, they can check to see if they have the matching Cure Card for that case. If they don't, they can either keep moving on subsequent turns to try to find and reach the matching case, or they can make their way back to Dr. Quack's house to pick up another cure. The other way to get an additional Cure Card is to spin a 6, 9, or 10 - then you can choose to take a card instead of moving that turn.

Once a player makes a cure match, they collect that case card, which indicates a number of points on it. When all cases have been cured, the player with the most total points wins.

Make the most of being stuck at home with the Monopoly At Home Reality game. This family board game celebrates the new way of living. Board spaces are rooms in the house -- the bedroom is the office, the living room is the movie theater, and the kitchen is the school.

The gameplay is similar to the standard Monopoly board game but with humorous differences. Tokens can't share a space because of social distancing, and players will want to watch out for the screaming child because they'll have to pay to entertain the kid.

This version of the Monopoly game makes the most of life at home with social distancing and missed activities like visiting a movie theater, yoga studio, and more.

     HILARIOUS TOKENS: Racecar with parking boot, Rubber duck with babies, T-Rex with boxer shorts, smaller dog, penguin with coffee cup, Cat with bath cap., 
     UPDATED UTILITIES AND HOME-THEMED BOARD SPACES: In this family board game, WiFi and video streaming are necessary utilities, and board spaces are places in the home, such as the kitchen turned school.
     AVOID THE SCREAMING CHILD: When a player moves their token, they also move the screaming child; if the tokens land on the same space, the player must pay to entertain the screaming child.


"Community Chest" becomes the "Community Cupboard". Chance is still called Chance, but is now illustrated with boxes shipped from online orders.

The money tweaks the classic design to look like a house, and each denomination features different food items inside the 'house'.

Each player has to move his 4 meeples along the track to the spaces of his own color to win the game. The players take turns to throw die die and move a meeple accordingly. If a meeple gets on a space occupied by the meeple of another player, the latter is thrown out and has to start again. There are also  spaces from where the meeples jump many spaces ahead like in Snakes and Ladders, so from space 32 to space 82 or from space 166 to 204. In the game for 6 players the blue corner spaces allow an extra move forward.

Ignacio Zambrano, a successful merchant, was found dead in the back room of his shop. How did he die? Who is responsible for that? And why? Follow the instructions with your investigation team and try to answer these and many other questions. Can you clear up the mysterious death of the merchant?

In each Q case, you try to solve a mystery case with 32 clues, with players revealing one clue at a time until all cards have been revealed or discarded. During your turn, each player must perform one of the following actions:

Choose a card from your hand and place it on the table, so all players can read or see the entire information.
We recomend you read out loud all shared info when you place it on the table. If you play a clue that happens to be irrelevant
to the case, you lose points at the end of the game, but be careful! Some clues are vital to resolve the case.

You can share and expose your theories at any moment and talk about the cards you have in your hand but you cannot show them to the other players and you may only read out loud the words written in bold or the text framed inside an image:

At the end of the game, when all clue cards have been revealed or discarded, you must check carefully all the available information and prepare a theory of what happened, working all together. Then, open the questionnaire and answer all questions. During this phase of the game, you can speak freely about your discarded cards, or the information you remember of them. Each right answer will add two points.

El Turista is a game published by Botella Roja in conjunction with the municipality of Catamarca Capital, the game was born by an initiative for cultural activities where we have to reach the tourist spots of this province.

For this we will use our Kilometers cards to cover the necessary distance, but beware that other tourists can prevent us from reaching our destinations with cards of adversity. The first tourist to reach 20 victory points is the winner!

Medo is a minimalist 2-player strategy game inspired by the idea of flowers competing for space in a meadow.

It was designed as part of the author's long time effort to create accessible games with emergent complexity.

Overview

One player owns dark and light blue stones, and the other player owns dark and light red stones.

The players take turns, placing stones on the initially-empty board, trying to capture groups of opponent stones. You capture opponent groups either when they’re surrounded or they’ve grown too large. The first player to capture a certain number of stones (depending on board size) wins.

This print-and-play game, based on the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, was designed and is being published through Paizo's Pathfinder/Starfinder Infinite license, and therefore is only available through PathfinderInfinite.com. It builds upon the foundations set by the award-winning game designed by Lone Shark Games and creates a whole new science-fantasy themed game.

In the Starfinder Infinite Adventure Card Game, you will play as a member of the Starfinder organization, increasing your character's power through feats as you play through several scenarios. The goal in many scenarios is to corner and defeat the villain, but there are lots of scenarios that have alternate win conditions. You'll pick up boon cards on your way, customizing your deck and improving your chances to succeed at defeating enemies and barriers.

If you're into the Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, you're sure to love this homage to it!

—description from the designer

The Charming family is an eclectic family that lives in a manor on top of the hill in the town of Banebridge somewhere in New England circa 1932.  They own the local mortuary as well as a mining company.  All they want to do is live in peace, take care of their ancestral home, run their businesses, and get along with the townsfolk.  The villagers of Banebridge, however, see it differently.  Many of them are firm of the opinion that at least some if not all of the “Charming” family are up to nefarious deeds and are, in fact, “monsters” of various sorts. To that end, they are constantly turning up evidence that implicates members of the family in foul play. Some villagers even start stalking individual members. Sometimes (well, a lot of the time really), the family members are forced to take action to deal with especially difficult villagers or incriminating evidence. Actions include Murder, Terrify, Beguile, Deceive, Extort, Bribe, Coerce, and many more. Of course, the family would NEVER take such actions if the villagers weren’t constantly interfering.


Gathering Gloom is a cooperative game for 1-4 monsters in which the players take on the role of a Witch, a Mad Scientist, a Vampire, a Werewolf, a Zombie, or a Ghost and work to resolve a series of crises at their mansion and businesses. Each character has one or more special abilities and some have vulnerabilities.  They use their own attributes as well as those of villagers they have beguiled into minions along with resources on their “Misdeed” cards to resolve 14-16 crises in order to win the game. Gloom gathers every turn based on events as well as from Evidence or Peril cards.  If the gloom reaches 50 or more before resolving all the crises, the players lose. Also, if the fear that the villagers have about anyone player reaches twelve or more, the family is exposed and the players lose.
   
The village has seven locations to visit along with three family locations on the board. There are many things to do on the map since each location has a unique action the player can take.  There are also alternate buildings that can be selected at setup to add variety to play.

On your turn, you roll dice to determine events. Then you can move to any location on the board, where you may activate an on-arrival action; you may use cards to perform other actions; you may resolve crises in family locations. Finally, you check to see if any villagers or stalkers are going to activate. You draw up for your next turn, and you are done.

-description from designer

Chase of the Bismarck is played in turns, each representing nearly five hours of real time. In each turn, both players secretly move any or all ships and air units under their command on their own search board.

Each player may then call out zones in which he has enough search factors to locate his opponent's ships. This is the “operational part of the game”.

If opposing ships are discovered to be in the same zone, they may proceed to combat on the Battle Board. This is the “tactical part of the game”.

Battle is resolved with a fairly simplified system, with both players moving on a map indicating the distance to their opponent's ships.

The game ends if the Bismarck is sunk, arrives at a friendly port or the last turn of the game (evening of May 29th) has been played.

Dungeon Party is an easy-to-learn, raucous, play-anywhere, social role-playing game, where the rooms, monsters, and treasures are all on bar coasters. Players take turns bouncing a coin to "hit" the monsters, disarm traps, or avoid cursed rooms. Players work together to survive the dungeon and gather the most loot, but there can only be one winner!

On their turn, a player reveals a room and monster, battles the monster, and recovers treasure. The game ends if all players’ characters are defeated in an encounter and the adventure failed, or if the last Boss monster has been defeated and the adventure has succeeded and you win.

Our first 2021 Holiday PNP is Yule Tides, a spin off of Tides designed by Mike Berg. In this 1 card microgame, 2 players will be collecting ingredients and baking tasty holiday treats! This came together as a single card game challenge on our discord, and turned out to be really fun.

—description from the publisher

A sugoroku game released on official Zelda merchandise. This was on the back of a pencil board and did not include any tokens, but did include a number of stickers.

It is just sugoroku and covers the first part of A Link to the Past up until the fight with Agahnim.

On your turn, you roll the dice and move your token. Occasionally, you must play rock-paper-scissors against opponents to proceed. The first to reach the end and defeat Agahnim wins.

Only the board, rules, and stickers were provided. User must provide dice and tokens.

Ys Sugoroku was originally published in æœˆåˆŠã‚³ãƒŸãƒƒã‚¯ã‚³ãƒ³ãƒ—ã€€published on May 20th, 1991. It is obviously based on the Ys video game series, but in this case derives all of its art from the late 80s/early 90s manga by Hagoromo ShÅ.

To play the game, you roll the dice and move your token. The first to defeat the boss at the end of the board wins.

Certain tiles along the way to the end have special directions that must be followed should you land there.

Only the board and rules were provided.  User must provide dice and tokens.

Everyone wants them: the juicy, colorful, freshly ripened tomato rarities that can be acquired throughout the extraordinary and glamorous Tomatomats.  Try to use the coins on the appropriate Tomatomats; but don't use them too obviously! And for God's sake: watch out for the hungry thieves who don’t hesitate to steal all coins in order to get the coveted tomatoes for themselves. Fortunately, a couple of cops are whirling around trying to chase the thieves. Who will earn the most tomatoes in this funny and foolish card-game, full of confusion and bluffs, and most importantly… about the beloved tomatoes!

Each player receives 12 cards, which can be coins, thieves, or cops. Each player plays all cards in four columns (face down!), belonging to one of the four displayed Tomatomats – after everyone has played all cards, the cards will be revealed and the effects executed, in this order: Cops remove thieves (of the same color); thieves remove coins (of the same color); coins might bring tomatoes! Only the player remaining with the highest value of coins may receive the corresponding Tomatomat.

The game ends after 3 or 4 rounds (depending on the number of players) – the player with the most Tomatomat-stars is the winner!

Card game IQ Ring: No. 2 is an educational question-and-answer game. The game consists of a set of 90 cards with questions, 12 special cards to track the score, 4 player figures, 8 surprise cards and an answer book. Each question card contains 3 questions of different difficulty. The first question is worth 1 point, the second 2 points and the third 3 points.
The game progresses in a clockwise direction. First, the question and surprise cards are shuffled into one deck. The player on the left then draws the card. If it is a question card - the player chooses one of the 3 questions and tries to answer it. If the answer is correct, the player goes as far as the question was worth. If incorrect, stay standing or go back if indicated on a special card. If the surprise card is pulled out, what is written on it is executed. The winner is the one who first scores 12 points.
This game can be expanded with IQ Ring: No. 1 and IQ Ring: No. 3 cards.

Kiekvienoje klausimÅ³ kortelÄ—je yra po 3 skirtingo sudÄ—tingumo klausimus. Pirmas klausimas vertas 1 taško, antras – 2, treÄias – 3 taškÅ³.

Jei neteisingas, lieka stovÄ—ti vietoje arba eina atgal jei taip yra nurodyta specialioje kortelÄ—je. Jei yra ištraukiama netikÄ—tumo kortelÄ—, vykdoma tai, kas joje parašyta. ŠÄ¯ Å¾aidimÄ… galima praplÄ—sti su "IQ ringas: Nr. 1" ir "IQ ringas: Nr. 3" kortomis.

A 3 dimensional 4-in-a-row game.  Players use cubes or cylindrical game pieces to be the first to get 4 in a row up, accross or diagonally on any level in any direction. That's it.

The game board is a 4 x4 grid.  On your turn, place your gamepiece on any space of the grid or stack it on top of any piece that has already been played.

It starts out simple but quickly creates many opportunities to win... or lose.

On the flip side of the board, play alternate versions. "The Wall" is a straight version that plays just like Connect Four.
"Stonehenge" is a circular version.  All have the same rule of 4 in a row in any direction.

—description from the designer

Walk around the city taking photos, be a photography student accompanied by the Professor.

Enjoy unique games, you will always play on a different map, your experiences will be different and the strategy will depend on your imagination.
The map is built with cards and players must advance towards the objectives.

Are you ready to become an expert photographer? Whoever achieves the best CLICS will be the winner of the game.

Pasea por la ciudad sacando fotos, asume el rol de un estudiante de fotografía acompañado del Profe.

Disfruta de partidas únicas, ya que jugarás siempre sobre un mapa diferente, tus experiencias serán distintas y la estrategia dependerá de tu imaginación.

¿Estás listo para convertirte en un fotógrafo experto? Quien logre los mejores CLICS, será el ganador de la partida.

Dado Batalla ("Battle Dice") is a board game designed for the little ones, to share and have a nice time with the family.
The main objective of this game is to mark all the numbers of an opponent with the marker tiles as soon as possible. You must roll the dice and mark your opponent's numbers.
Whoever does it first will be the winner of the game!

El “Dado Batalla” es un juego de mesa pensado para los más pequeños, para compartir y pasar un lindo rato en familia.
El objetivo principal de este juego es marcar todos los números de un contrincante con las fichas marcadoras lo antes posible.
Quien lo haga primero, será el ganador de la partida!

Load up your vehicle with supplies, strap on a few weapons, and prepare to make your wreckland run.

Wreckland Run takes place in a post-apocalyptic landscape known as the Wrecklands that's filled with marauders and other dangers. Wreckland Run is played across a campaign consisting of 7 chapters. With each new chapter, the continuing story will unfold in the campaign book. You will be instructed to open up a new envelope that adds exciting new bosses, enemies, and gameplay twists. The contents of these are secret for now. Do not reveal them until you’ve been instructed to!

At the start of the campaign, you will first choose a vehicle and driver. Choose wisely, as this will be your combination that you’ll carry across all 7 chapters. Once you’ve completed a chapter, you will move on to the next chapter in the campaign, but the enemies and Parts you’ve encountered will remain in their decks, increasing the power of your arsenal but also the ferocity of your foes!

The game is played over three rounds, each consisting of two phases, Wreckage and then Run. In Wreckage you'll repair and outfit your vehicle with new and upgraded parts. In the Run phase, you battle enemies over a series of turns, and hopefully survive to fight another day! You win by defeating the Boss in the third and final round of the game!

—description from the publisher

Players cooperatively build a city distributing and placing tiles to build a city. There are three public goals and everyone gets their personal goals, representing demands from different groups of people living in the city. Players can discuss al they like before the tiles are distributed but once the project manager hands out tiles, everyone places them without communicating. The goal of the game is to score as many points as possible, representing how happy the people living in the city are.

—user summary

Battlefields is a tactical combat game between two armies of heroes from the Catacombs universe. First, players spend points to draft their army of heroes, then they place their chosen heroes on the hex-based neoprene playmat. Different heroes have different movement rates and attacks. Combat is resolved by either dexterity (dice flicking) or non-dexterity mechanisms.

The game provides a variety of units for both the Heroic and Lich Lord forces and supports two players. It also features a solo mode.

—description from the publisher

Player of the Game Tennis is much like our other games in the Player of the Game lineup. It plays rapidly, but offers enough detail and action to give you the story of the match.

In Player of the Game Tennis, each player is individually rated for their service game both first serves and second serves; their complete ability when receiving (again how they handle the opponent's first serve or second serve); ability to hit game winners or game losers in some cases. Other factors, like a player's fitness, whether he is a favorite, ability to handle adversity, major and minor injuries are all included. Did we mention that all of the factors above are broken down by playing surface? All aspects of a tennis match are covered.

Player of the Game is easy to learn and easy to understand. You'll be playing in no time. Each match will unfold in front of your eyes at a brisk pace. A full match in Player of the Game tennis take no longer than 10 minutes. Most matches will be completed in 5 minutes!

The base game includes a fictional Men's Tour and a fictional Women's Tour with complete schedules, prize money, a points system, and even tournament brackets. Everything needed to play is included in the base game.

If you want to add real players, you can purchase any of our season year books.

If your favorite player isn't rated (which isn't likely), we give you a method to put them in the game!

The Printed game features all players on die-cut cards printed in vivid color.

Step on the court today, it is all Aces with Player of the Game Tennis!

—description from the designer

Chicken Thief is a real time game of observation and quick reaction! In includes 3 games, for different children development levels:

A) Grab the Chicken
Cornelia the Chicken is craving a treat of a specific color! Check your card. If you have that color, be the first to grab the chicken by the neck, to get rid of your card!

B) Coop Party
Cornelia the Chicken is now asking for a specific number of veggies!Count the veggies on your cards and if they match the number, grab the chicken first to get rid of them!

C) Go Figure!
This time, Cornelia the Chicken is asking for specific items. Search among the cards spread on the table and be the first to spot the item to win its card. First player with 7 cards, wins the game!

—description from the designer

Trivia Buzzer game, with an LCD screen, in which luck and good judgement also matter!

It includes 2 modes of difficulty, one for children and one for the whole family.

In your turn, you move your pawn on the board, answering questions to gather points. On special squares, everyone can bet on whether the active player will answer correctly, to win some extra points. Race first your pawn to the finish line and be the player with the most points to win the game!

—description from the designer

4 games for the first handling of numbers are offered in this collection for the pupils of the 1st and 2nd grade elementary school.

Card pairs trains memory and continuous counting, you uncover pairs of cards with the same value or the same number or the same number and write down the value of two pairs found in several scores, who has the highest sum at the end, wins.

Fast task rotation poses arithmetic tasks with the help of the rotating arrow, first number tiles are uncovered, with which then the task is to be solved, who achieves the highest sum from two of three results, wins.

Arithmetic Quiz requires solving arithmetic problems in two difficulty levels for first and second grade.

Shape Puzzles provides a first look at geometric shapes and how they interact for larger and other shapes by laying shapes analogous to Tangram. The laying puzzles give the new shape and the number of pieces given for it, while the corner puzzles give the pieces needed and the number of corners the new figure must have.

The whole neighbourhood competes to see who can decorate their house in the most tasteful, elegant display of brightly- coloured lights in the run-up to Christmas. Every square metre of your house has to be blasting out light if you want to stand a chance of out-Holidaying the Joneses!

2-4 players compete to put on the most impressive Christmas lights on the front of their houses by spending cards to build their decks, install power lines and put up decorations, drawing their display out on individual grids. When the big day comes you don't want to be left with unpowered lights or empty walls.

Decs Building is intended to be printed on the inside face of a Christmas card to friends or family, and in addition to the self-contained card, requires only components many families will already have around their houses: coloured pawns from e.g. Ludo or Pachesi, a couple of decks of regular playing cards, and a pen or pencil and paper for each player.

—description from the designer

This game combines with the Battle for Germany game and the Battle for the Balkans game to cover the entire European Front in a hypothetical World War Three in 1985.

The game will add additional rules, which can be retrofitted in the previous games, for naval warfare.

Norway, Sweden, and Finland will be covered showing the Warsaw Pact attack on these countries.  Denmark's role will be expanded.

—description from the designer

Cryptopia is a fast paced blockchain asset building & trading game where players collect development, influence and funding and invest it into their blockchains. Player's will leverage strategy cards that can improve position and attack other player's asset. Cryptopia involves strategy, wits and a bit of luck!


     Collect funding, development and influence assets cards inspired by actual events relating to crypto
     Use strategy cards to remove, steal or trade other player's assets.
     Strategically invest assets cards to improve position
     Watch out for attacks from other players


Choose your blockchain and reach market dominance

—description from the designer

The lair of Jabba, the Hutt is a place of danger and deception. Players compete using members of the Rebel Alliance and denizens of Jabba’s Palace in a game of rebel bravery and vile deceit.

Based on the beloved card game and set in the Star Wars galaxy, Star Wars: Jabba’s Palace - A Love Letter Game retains the simple and fun mechanics of the original as you utilize the talents of iconic characters from Return of the Jedi. Players take turns using the elegant “draw a card, play a card” gameplay and then executing the card’s effect. Cards include characters like Luke Skywalker, Boba Fett, Salacious Crumb, Jabba the Hutt, and many more, with each card offering different effects, such as Boba Fett allowing you to take a card from another player, or Salacious Crumb allowing you to look at another player’s hand.

Players use abilities from members of both the Rebel Alliance and Jabba’s crew to outwit and outlast the others. On top of the classic mechanics from the original Love Letter game, Star Wars: Jabba’s Palace - A Love Letter Game also introduces Agenda cards. This offers new win conditions, adding another level of strategy to the game.

Agenda cards like Exalted One awards the player with the highest number in hand the win. However, cards like Jabba’s Court and Rescue Mission switch it up and award the victory to the player with the most Palace or Rebels cards, respectively, in the play area. These and other Agenda cards ensure varied strategies will be needed with every game beyond simply eliminating other players.

In a quick card game of rebel bravery and vile deceit, can you carry out your agenda while outthinking your foes?

-description from publisher's website
The seventh expansion for Blanc-manger Coco, 200 cultivation-themed cards, for grown-ups, bodybuilders, for everyone indeed.
